repnme.cdata!:
Rwanda - Urban infrastructure and city
            management tools

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about Rwanda
            Urban Infrastructure and City Management Project. Rapid
            urbanization in Rwanda, had resulted in unplanned and
            squalid settlements, urban sprawl, and increased urban
            poverty. The Rwanda Urban Infrastructure and City Management
            Project was designed to improve the provision of priority
            infrastructure and services in the urban areas. The
            construction of 22.6 kilometers of asphalt and stone paved
            roads, reduced the transport costs for the urban population
            by 60 percent. The construction of three primary schools,
            health care center and youth center improved the social
            infrastructure benefitting the people in urban areas. The
            bus terminals built under the project, facilitated
            inter-district movement within the city and improved
            linkages with the neighboring areas resulting in improved
            economic infrastructure.

TF052413-PHRD-RWANDA: URBAN

repnme.cdata!:
Rwanda - Urban Infrastructure and City
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Urban Infrastructure and
            City Management Project for Rwanda were as follows: outcomes
            were highly satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was highly satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: the city contract approach can be an
            efficient tool to facilitate improvements in service
            delivery and municipal and urban management, and to
            accompany decentralization, even within a limited timeframe.
            The project confirmed findings from other urban development
            projects in the Africa region that this approach and its
            tools (priority investment program, priority maintenance
            program, municipal support program, and financial ratios)
            can be used to effectively link infrastructure financing,
            maintenance, and capacity building. The city contract
            approach is flexible and could be adapted to the Rwandan
            context. It proved highly effective in focusing activities
            on results in a context marked by a combination of lack of
            capacity and rapidly evolving decentralization. Bank
            safeguard policies can be used as a basis for a constructive
            dialogue on management of social and environmental impacts
            of development efforts in general, bringing about changes
            that reach beyond the project context. Land management is
            highly sensitive in Rwanda and the needs for slum upgrading
            are immense. Clearly demonstrating the benefits of a
            market-based land valuation and participatory approach to
            determining compensation led to changed approaches to slum
            upgrading and resettlement, with a focus on the needs of the
            affected populations. With the majority of the urban
            population living in slums, recognition of their needs and
            rights is an important element in sound urban land management.

9459326.trustfund:
TF052413-PHRD-RWANDA: URBAN
            INFRASTRUCTURE AND CITY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM

repnme.cdata!:
Rwanda - Urban infrastructure and city
            management project

abstracts.cdata!:
This report indicates that the
            infrastructure and urban management project aims to increase
            access to urban infrastructure and services in the city of
            Kigali and in two secondary cities - Butare and Ruhengeri.
            This will be achieved through the combined effect of two
            types of interventions: 1) Implementation of advanced
            investments and adjustment programs identified through a
            participatory process in targeted cities; and 2)
            Introduction of management tools to improve programming and
            financing, and enforcement of mechanisms in the delivery of
            services; improve local resource mobilization; develop
            simple tools for urban planning; and streamline municipal
            management and maintenance.

repnme.cdata!:
Rwanda - Urban Infrastructure and City
            Management Project : resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Urban Infrastructure and City
            Management Project seeks to improve services, and
            infrastructure in urban areas in Rwanda, including the
            institutional capacity in urban management, through
            sustainable mechanisms in its programming, financing, and
            implementation. It is thus foreseen that land acquisition,
            and resettlement will occur due to infrastructure
            development, therefore, this resettlement plan sets the
            standards for compensation due to resettlement issues, i.e.,
            land, income, and assets losses. Land replacement for land
            losses, shall take into consideration equal size and
            productive value, to improve or at least restore living
            conditions, while construction materials shall be provided
            for housing, and any structure losses; additionally,
            equipment losses shall also be replaced. Project affected
            persons (PAPs) will have the choice of cash compensations
            for assets lost, estimated in the local currency, at market
            values, provided replacement costs are not acceptable to
            PAPs. Employment opportunities and training assistance will
            be provided to ensure income restoration. Moving expenses
            and additional assistance shall be provided during the
            transition period, while grievance mechanisms will be
            established should conflict occur.
